name: Fionnuala

attributes.attribute: left as swans with human emotions and human voices to sing of their woes
finally on an island in the far west
local legend in west Co. Cork also claims they lived there

sources: Gantz, Jeffrey, ed. and trans. Early Irish Myths and Sagas. New York: Penguin Books, 1984, 147+.
Gregory, Lady Augusta. Gods and Fighting Men: The Story of the Tuatha De Danaan and of the Fianna of Ireland. New York: Oxford University Press, 1970, 124+.
Joyce, Patrick Weston. Ancient Celtic Romances. London: Parkgate Books, 1997.
Kennedy, Patrick. Legendary Fictions of the Irish Celts. (New York: Benjamin Blom, 1969), 27.
Markale, Jean. Women of the Celts. Rochester, Vt.: Inner Traditions, 1986, 242.
Squire, Charles. Mythology of the Celtic People. London: Bracken Books, 1996, 142.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Irish heroine Fionnuala, also known as Finola, Finnguala, Fionguala, Finnuala, and Fionnula, is the subject of one of the most popular Irish myths. She was the daughter of King Lir and his first wife Áeb, who was the daughter of the magician Bodb Derg. Fionnuala and her twin brother Áed were born to a happy couple, but tragedy struck when Áeb passed away during childbirth of their second set of twin sons, Fiachra and Conn. Lir, hoping to make a happy home for his motherless children, married his wife’s foster sister Aífe who was jealous of the children and plotted against them. She convinced Lir that she was ill and needed her foster father’s attention, taking the children to Bodb Derg’s home in the west. However, along the way, she transformed them into swans and cursed them to remain so for 900 years. Despite Bodb Derg’s magic, the enchantment couldn't be undone. The Children of Lir were left as swans with human emotions and voices to sing of their woes. For 300 years, they lived on Lough Derravaragh in central Ireland, then another 300 years on the frigid Sea of Moyle to the north, and finally on an island off Co. Mayo. The enchantment finally wore off, but the years caught up with them instantly, and they aged, died, and turned to dust. They were buried in the old way, standing upright in the grave.
